speaker: JULIA
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: SCENE I. Milan. The DUKE's palace.

speaker: JULIA
text_entry: Enter DUKE, THURIO, and PROTEUS

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: We have some secrets to confer about.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exit THURIO

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now, tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My gracious lord, that which I would discover

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The law of friendship bids me to conceal;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But when I call to mind your gracious favours

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Done to me, undeserving as I am,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: My duty pricks me on to utter that

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which else no worldly good should draw from me.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine, my friend,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: This night intends to steal away your daughter:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Myself am one made privy to the plot.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I know you have determined to bestow her

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And should she thus be stol'n away from you,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: It would be much vexation to your age.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: To cross my friend in his intended drift

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Than, by concealing it, heap on your head

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A pack of sorrows which would press you down,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Which to requite, command me while I live.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This love of theirs myself have often seen,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Haply when they have judged me fast asleep,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And oftentimes have purposed to forbid

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Valentine her company and my court:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But fearing lest my jealous aim might err

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And so unworthily disgrace the man,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: A rashness that I ever yet have shunn'd,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That which thyself hast now disclosed to me.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, that thou mayst perceive my fear of this,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I nightly lodge her in an upper tower,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: The key whereof myself have ever kept;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And thence she cannot be convey'd away.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: How he her chamber-window will ascend

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And with a corded ladder fetch her down;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For which the youthful lover now is gone

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And this way comes he with it presently;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Where, if it please you, you may intercept him.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But, good my Lord, do it so cunningly

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That my discovery be not aimed at;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For love of you, not hate unto my friend,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Upon mine honour, he shall never know

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That I had any light from thee of this.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Adieu, my Lord; Sir Valentine is coming.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Enter VALENTINE

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Please it your grace, there is a messenger

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That stays to bear my letters to my friends,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And I am going to deliver them.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Be they of much import?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: The tenor of them doth but signify

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My health and happy being at your court.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Nay then, no matter; stay with me awhile;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I am to break with thee of some affairs

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I know it well, my Lord; and, sure, the match

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Were rich and honourable; besides, the gentleman

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is full of virtue, bounty, worth and qualities

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Cannot your Grace win her to fancy him?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: No, trust me; she is peevish, sullen, froward,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Neither regarding that she is my child

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Nor fearing me as if I were her father;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, where I thought the remnant of mine age

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Should have been cherish'd by her child-like duty,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I now am full resolved to take a wife

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And turn her out to who will take her in:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Then let her beauty be her wedding-dower;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For me and my possessions she esteems not.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: There is a lady in Verona here

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Whom I affect; but she is nice and coy

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And nought esteems my aged eloquence:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For long agone I have forgot to court;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Besides, the fashion of the time is changed--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How and which way I may bestow myself

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Win her with gifts, if she respect not words:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Dumb jewels often in their silent kind

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: A woman sometimes scorns what best contents her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Send her another; never give her o'er;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For scorn at first makes after-love the more.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But rather to beget more love in you:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For why, the fools are mad, if left alone.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Take no repulse, whatever she doth say;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: For 'get you gone,' she doth not mean 'away!'

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But she I mean is promised by her friends

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Unto a youthful gentleman of worth,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And kept severely from resort of men,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That no man hath access by day to her.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, then, I would resort to her by night.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay, but the doors be lock'd and keys kept safe,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That no man hath recourse to her by night.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What lets but one may enter at her window?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And built so shelving that one cannot climb it

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Without apparent hazard of his life.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why then, a ladder quaintly made of cords,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To cast up, with a pair of anchoring hooks,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Would serve to scale another Hero's tower,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: So bold Leander would adventure it.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: When would you use it? pray, sir, tell me that.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This very night; for Love is like a child,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That longs for every thing that he can come by.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But, hark thee; I will go to her alone:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Under a cloak that is of any length.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Ay, my good lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Then let me see thy cloak:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I'll get me one of such another length.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What letter is this same? What's here? 'To Silvia'!

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And here an engine fit for my proceeding.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Reads

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And slaves they are to me that send them flying:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: O, could their master come and go as lightly,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Himself would lodge where senseless they are lying!

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: While I, their king, that hither them importune,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Do curse the grace that with such grace hath bless'd them,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Because myself do want my servants' fortune:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I curse myself, for they are sent by me,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: That they should harbour where their lord would be.'

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What's here?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee.'

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: 'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Why, Phaeton,--for thou art Merops' son,--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And with thy daring folly burn the world?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Wilt thou reach stars, because they shine on thee?

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Go, base intruder! overweening slave!

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And think my patience, more than thy desert,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Is privilege for thy departure hence:

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thank me for this more than for all the favours

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Which all too much I have bestow'd on thee.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But if thou linger in my territories

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Longer than swiftest expedition

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Will give thee time to leave our royal court,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: By heaven! my wrath shall far exceed the love

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: I ever bore my daughter or thyself.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Be gone! I will not hear thy vain excuse;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: But, as thou lovest thy life, make speed from hence.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And why not death rather than living torment?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: To die is to be banish'd from myself;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And Silvia is myself: banish'd from her

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is self from self: a deadly banishment!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What light is light, if Silvia be not seen?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Unless it be to think that she is by

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And feed upon the shadow of perfection

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Except I be by Silvia in the night,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: There is no music in the nightingale;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Unless I look on Silvia in the day,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: There is no day for me to look upon;

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: She is my essence, and I leave to be,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If I be not by her fair influence

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Foster'd, illumined, cherish'd, kept alive.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Tarry I here, I but attend on death:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: But, fly I hence, I fly away from life.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS and LAUNCE

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Run, boy, run, run, and seek him out.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Soho, soho!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What seest thou?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Him we go to find: there's not a hair on's head

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: but 'tis a Valentine.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Valentine?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Who then? his spirit?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Neither.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: What then?

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Nothing.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Who wouldst thou strike?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Nothing.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Villain, forbear.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing: I pray you,--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sirrah, I say, forbear. Friend Valentine, a word.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: My ears are stopt and cannot hear good news,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: So much of bad already hath possess'd them.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For they are harsh, untuneable and bad.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Is Silvia dead?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: No, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No Valentine, indeed, for sacred Silvia.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Hath she forsworn me?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: No, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: What is your news?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That thou art banished--O, that's the news!--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: From hence, from Silvia and from me thy friend.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: O, I have fed upon this woe already,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: And now excess of it will make me surfeit.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ay, ay; and she hath offer'd to the doom--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which, unreversed, stands in effectual force--

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Those at her father's churlish feet she tender'd;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With them, upon her knees, her humble self;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As if but now they waxed pale for woe:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But neither bended knees, pure hands held up,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Besides, her intercession chafed him so,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: When she for thy repeal was suppliant,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That to close prison he commanded her,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With many bitter threats of biding there.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: No more; unless the next word that thou speak'st

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Have some malignant power upon my life:

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: If so, I pray thee, breathe it in mine ear,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And study help for that which thou lament'st.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Time is the nurse and breeder of all good.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And manage it against despairing thoughts.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Which, being writ to me, shall be deliver'd

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The time now serves not to expostulate:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And, ere I part with thee, confer at large

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Of all that may concern thy love-affairs.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As thou lovest Silvia, though not for thyself,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Regard thy danger, and along with me!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: I pray thee, Launce, an if thou seest my boy,

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Bid him make haste and meet me at the North-gate.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: O my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!

speaker: VALENTINE
text_entry: Exeunt VALENTINE and PROTEUS

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I am but a fool, look you; and yet I have the wit to

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: think my master is a kind of a knave: but that's

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: all one, if he be but one knave. He lives not now

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: that knows me to be in love; yet I am in love; but a

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: team of horse shall not pluck that from me; nor who

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman; but what woman, I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: a maid, for she is her master's maid, and serves for

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel;

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: which is much in a bare Christian.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Pulling out a paper

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Here is the cate-log of her condition.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: 'Imprimis: She can fetch and carry.' Why, a horse

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: can do no more: nay, a horse cannot fetch, but only

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: carry; therefore is she better than a jade. 'Item:

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: She can milk;' look you, a sweet virtue in a maid

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: with clean hands.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Enter SPEED

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: How now, Signior Launce! what news with your

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: mastership?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: With my master's ship? why, it is at sea.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Well, your old vice still; mistake the word. What

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: news, then, in your paper?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: The blackest news that ever thou heardest.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why, man, how black?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, as black as ink.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Let me read them.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Fie on thee, jolt-head! thou canst not read.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Thou liest; I can.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I will try thee. Tell me this: who begot thee?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: O illiterate loiterer! it was the son of thy

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: grandmother: this proves that thou canst not read.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Come, fool, come; try me in thy paper.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: There; and St. Nicholas be thy speed!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: [Reads]  'Imprimis: She can milk.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Ay, that she can.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She brews good ale.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: And thereof comes the proverb: 'Blessing of your

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: heart, you brew good ale.'

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can sew.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That's as much as to say, Can she so?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can knit.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: she can knit him a stock?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can wash and scour.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: A special virtue: for then she need not be washed

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: and scoured.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She can spin.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: spin for her living.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath many nameless virtues.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That's as much as to say, bastard virtues; that,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: indeed, know not their fathers and therefore have no names.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Here follow her vices.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Close at the heels of her virtues.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is not to be kissed fasting in respect

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: of her breath.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath a sweet mouth.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That makes amends for her sour breath.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She doth talk in her sleep.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is slow in words.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: be slow in words is a woman's only virtue: I pray

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is proud.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy, and cannot

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: be ta'en from her.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath no teeth.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is curst.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She will often praise her liquor.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: If her liquor be good, she shall: if she will not, I

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: will; for good things should be praised.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She is too liberal.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I'll keep shut: now, of another thing she may, and

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit, and more faults

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: than hairs, and more wealth than faults.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Stop there; I'll have her: she was mine, and not

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: mine, twice or thrice in that last article.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Rehearse that once more.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'Item: She hath more hair than wit,'--

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: More hair than wit? It may be; I'll prove it. The

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: is more than the wit, for the greater hides the

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: less. What's next?

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'And more faults than hairs,'--

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: That's monstrous: O, that that were out!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: 'And more wealth than faults.'

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well,

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: I'll have her; and if it be a match, as nothing is

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: impossible,--

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: What then?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Why, then will I tell thee--that thy master stays

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: for thee at the North-gate.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: For me?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: For thee! ay, who art thou? he hath stayed for a

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: better man than thee.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: And must I go to him?

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: that going will scarce serve the turn.

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Why didst not tell me sooner? pox of your love letters!

speaker: SPEED
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: secrets! I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Exit
